title: 'Now's our time, so let us shine': Women lead the way for Great Britain at World Athletics Championships
text:
In a sporting landscape where women are constantly striving for equality, athletics has a wonderful knack of flipping traditional gender hierarchies on its head. So at the end of these World Championships, Britain’s women will depart having contributed four medals - as well as the overwhelming majority of headlines - compared to just one from the men. When it comes to British athletics, right now it really is a woman’s world.

Dina Asher-Smith has led the way, with her record-breaking feat of becoming the first British athlete to win three medals at a single World Championships, courtesy of gold in the 200m and silver in the 100m and 4x100m relay. Katarina Johnson-Thompson also won a spectacular heptathlon title, while the men have just a solitary 4x100m silver to show for their efforts.

Rather than shy away from comparisons between men and women, Britain’s female sprint relay team were only too happy to embrace competition between the sexes the day after retaining their 4x100m silver.

Asked how it feels to see women earning all the headlines, Asha Philip said: “I feel great about that. It’s all about the women and it should have been.

“Now’s our time, so let us shine. It’s a good thing we’re talking about women. It’s always been a negative thought – it’s been about sport and then about us women. Now the boys aren’t getting a look in because we’re better.”
